entry.title: [SBv5] Add histograms for hash-prefix real-time checks on Android.
entry.content:
The following histograms are added as a follow up of

https://crrev.com/c/4779056, where we validate the response from

SafeBrowsing API:

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.JavaValidationResult

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.LookupResult

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.ResponseStatus

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.ThreatAttribute

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.ThreatAttributeCount

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.ThreatType



Note that LookupResult/ResponseStatus/ThreatAttribute/ThreatType are

logged as sparse histograms instead of enum histograms, because:

1) The buckets are not continuous or not always start from 0.

2) In rare circumstance, the value can be out of range, which may

cause base::UmaHistogramEnumeration to throw an exception.



The following histograms are added as a follow up of

https://crrev.com/c/4744760, where we expand RemoteDatabaseManager to

support both hash database and hash real time checks:

* SB2.RemoteCall.CanCheckUrl.{CheckType}

* SafeBrowsing.HPRT.CanGetReputationOfUrl



The following histogram is added as a follow up of

https://crrev.com/c/4805514, where we start to check the availability

of the API:

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.IsAvailable



Also add the following histogram to track the latency of the API:

* SafeBrowsing.GmsSafeBrowsingApi.CheckDelta



Bug: 1444511

entry.title: Invalidation on stylesheet changes using selector matching
entry.content:
When inserting, deleting or modifying stylesheets, we need to invalidate

style for some elements, even though the elements themselves did not

change. Currently, we reuse the concept of InvalidationSets, which are

mostly designed for changes to elements, for that. This can sometimes

cause overbroad invalidations, especially if the style is written in

a “modern” (read: less-than-ideal) fashion.



We replace this by a somewhat slower but more precise and probably

simpler system; for each candidate element in the DOM, we see if it

matches any selectors in the old or the new rulesets (by means of

the same bucketing logic we currently have during element rule

collection), and if so, we mark it for style recalc. This isn't perfect;

if we are e.g. adding a single rule to an existing stylesheet, we would

still invalidate based on all rules in the sheet. We hope to improve

this in a future patch, but even now, this shows significant

improvements over most of blink_perf.css, with only a few regressions.



Note that this means the experimental style invalidation information in

devtools becomes somewhat less useful; it will no longer give reasons

for invalidations when style sheets change. Fixing this would probably

involve extending the protocol, although I haven't looked deeply into

this.



Bug: 1444522

Change-Id: Ib95cf8d215bf4e7b58ab1955ebc1f3c7e31aead8

entry.title: Soda: parameterize ChromeOS installation to allow for multiple languages.
entry.content:
The Soda Installer currently only allowed, via a hardcoded mechanism,

en_us installation. This CL introduces a parameter for supported

languages, and the rest of the code will simply follow.



Adding a language is the matter of adding an appropriate entry during

construction of the installer. Notably, right now, there's only 1

language that is supported: en_us.



Note that the progress bar can be a little bit unusual, but that's not

super problematic. Notably the progress is averaged across all

installing languages, and doesn't go by bytes but rather package

percentages. This is identical to the current behavior, and is still

useful for clients.



Bug: b:257166700

Test: All unit tests pass.

entry.title: pip2: Add ability to resize to fit child dialogs
entry.content:
On certain platforms (Windows and Linux), child dialog windows such as

the page info dialog, the capture dialog, etc. cannot display outside

of the bounds of their parent browser window. This usually isn't an

issue, but since Document Picture-in-Picture windows are typically

small some dialogs will get clipped.



This CL adds logic into the picture-in-picture browser frame to be able

to temporarily resize itself when a larger child dialog is shown.

entry.title: Allow ParagraphUtils.buildNodeGroup to build a paragraph parented by given node
entry.content:
Currently, ParagraphUtils.buildNodeGroup never creates a paragraph using

a given node as a paragraph parent. However, this doesn't work well on

Android tree because we consider clickable as a paragraph (CL:4783269)

and it can be a leaf node. As a result, sometimes parent window is

selected as a paragraph parent, and all nodes are put under it.



This change allows ParagraphUtils.buildNodeGroup to build a paragraph

parented by given node if the node is clickable so that S2S can group

nodes better for Android tree.



Bug: b:297120988

Test: SelectToSpeakParagraphUnitTest

Test: Use a test app for ARC++ a11y tast test. S2S focuses on each clickable nodes.

Change-Id: I94324fcb15d29a5b73b34b6c9f75ce078e5140f0

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4809755

Reviewed-by: Jacob Francis

Commit-Queue: Hiroki Sato

Reviewed-by: Anastasia Helfinstein

entry.title: iwa: Maybe fix RegisterGarbageCollectionInstallGate crash
entry.content:
After discussion with rmcelrath@ and cmp@, we think this crash may be

caused by ExtensionService being null at the time of the

`RegisterInstallGate` call.



After further discussion with rmcelrath@, we decided to do the following

to mitigate the potential crash.



1. Making ExtensionSystemSharedFactory a dependency of

WebAppProviderFactory.

2. Use OnExtensionSystemReady to ensure ExtensionService is up before

Run().

3. Add a CHECK for extension_service_.

4. Resetting the 2 prefs (to false) early and force-writing them to disk

to ensure we skip the command on next startup if the command crashes.

5. As a side efffect of 4, we can no longer use WaitForPrefValue() in

the browser test. The temporary solution is to add a base::OneShotEvent

which fires when GC is complete. It will live in ExtensionsManager for

the time being for easier cherry-picking.







Bug: 1476377

entry.title: [reland] content: unconditionally populate frame_url in ContextMenuParams
entry.content:
The prior design only populated frame_url when the initiating frame was

a subframe, which led to code in quite a few places to use frame_url if

present and page_url otherwise, or to test for an empty frame_url as a

signal that the initiator was a subframe.



This change makes frame_url unconditional, and adds a separate parameter

for whether the initiator is a subframe. It also refactors

TestRenderViewContextMenu slightly to make some of the factory arguments

for that class optional, since nearly all call sites pass the same

values.



This is a preparatory refactor for a behavior change in passing invoker

origins through the context menu.



This change is a re-land of

https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4790929,

which introduced an MSan test failure because of the uninitialized

is_subframe member in ContextMenuParams.



Bug: 1457702

Change-Id: I7980017b0333fdfe4b421b8e2feda1320d41db4f

entry.title: Fix dependency cycle between generic_sensor mojom and cpp targets
entry.content:
https://crrev.com/c/4770860 introduced a dependency cycle between the

cpp and mojom bits that occurs when other parts of the tree start

passing SensorReading via Mojo: sensor_mojom_traits.cc, which is part of

the "generic_sensor" target in //services/device/public/mojom, now

depends on sensor_reading.{cc,h}, which is part of the "generic_sensor"

target in //services/device/public/cpp/generic_sensor. The latter

target, however, has a dependency on the former.



Fix it by moving sensor_reading.{cc,h} to a separate source_set (just

like we already do for platform_sensor_configuration.{cc,h}) and moving

SensorReadingSharedBuffer to a separate file, as it was the only part of

sensor_reading.{cc,h} that depended on the mojom target for the

mojom::SensorType enum.



The rest of this CL is just adjusting includes in all files that access

SensorReadingSharedBuffer.



Bug: 1278377

Change-Id: Ic835dc72233e49edf00437abc0ecb4ef80ef5d05

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4827064

entry.title: [Discounts] Update the shopping service offer notification if url has discount tag
entry.content:
This CL gets offers from ShoppingService asynchronously if the committed

URL contains the specific utm param and the

kNtpHistoryClustersModuleDiscounts feature flag is on. It's guaranteed

to have a shopping service offer for these kinds of URL. The

NotificationOfferIconView will show after callback return from

ShoppingService with the discount.



In addition, for url that has valid offers and doesn't have the correct

utm param, we still ask ShoppingService to get the FreeListing offer

asynchronously in a silence mode, which it will not trigger any

notification UIs.

entry.title: Commit selection as last step in closing combobox menu
entry.content:
When closing combobox menu, call `OnPerformAction()` last.

`OnPerformAction()` may call the selection change callback, which can

update the UI in ways not controlled by combobox - for example, delete

the Combobox view, or change combobox bounds (in which case we may end

up changing the combobox menu bounds unnecessarily). Making callback

invocation the last step minimizes chances of UAF.



BUG=b:298210659

entry.title: [Office] Prevent QuickOffice from intercepting document navigations
entry.content:
When users navigate to an URL with a MIME type that can be handled by

the QuickOffice extension (eg. a .docx, a .pptx etc), the navigation

is intercepted and the URL opened in QuickOffice instead of

downloading the file.



This behaviour can confuse users and on ChromeOS, a product decision was made to prevent it (as the downloaded file can be immediately opened in any editor, including QuickOffice, after download). Additionally, ChromeOS is introducing new, improved options for handling Office documents, and QuickOffice is at the start of being deprecated.



This CL adds a flag that changes this behaviour on ChromeOS so that navigations to supported file formats instead result in downloading the file.



Bug: b:295269799

Change-Id: I9b22674f33a19879e8d3fd5c3b5fc3a25fbc6446

entry.title: Reduce number of JNI calls when querying TabModel.
entry.content:
This change reduces volume of JNI calls, improving performance of any

logic that depends on TabModelList and PersistedTabDataAndroid.



TabModelList::GetTabModelForTabAndroid makes at least two JNI jumps

per every loop iteration: one to query tab model size, and another to

retrieve the Tab object; requesting data for 100th tab means 200 JNI

jumps; requesting data for N tabs means 2*N*(N+1)/2=~N² JNI jumps.



PersistedTabDataAndroid appears to be invoking this call twice

just in the constructor, so the change proposes making the Profile

instance more directly accessible.



Bug: 1337034

Change-Id: I1c90d5e7ae1965f6e41605c14fca8146d93d0c13

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4814669

entry.title: Factor out logic creating vertical suggestions group. Clean up code.
entry.content:
The change simplifies the method building suggestions group by

factoring out the part that builds a single vertical section. This

permits us to separately construct a horizontal suggestions group.



The change passes GroupConfig structure directly as part of the

ViewInfo to reduce number of unnecessary lookups.



The loop constructing suggestions list is now explicitly broken into

"creating individual suggestions sections", rather than creating the

entire list in one go.

This CL does a couple things:

1. Ensures the current text styles are logged when the side panel closes for both the views (existing) and webui (new) toolbars.

3. Uses the mojom enum for logging color, which is what should've been happening before, but when I made a new enum for it a few months ago, I didn't relize we had a mojom enum for it already.

entry.title: win: Stop AppHomePageHandlerTest creating shortcuts in startup dir
entry.content:
override_registration_ is reset in TearDownOnMainThread, but tasks

can be running on other threads that create shortcuts. This CL

uses a ScopedPathOverride which lives as long as the test fixture

to backstop override_registration_.



Ideally we can figure out how to reset override_registration_ after

all tasks have stopped, but for now, this is blocking the CL that

implements a general mechanism for stopping tests from writing to

special directories.

entry.title: Add an AdditionalBidKey to InterestGroups to support negative targeting.
entry.content:
Each additional bid may specify one or more negative targeting

InterestGroups. To guarantee that only the owner of those InterestGroups

may use them for negative targeting, each additional bid is signed with

one or more ed25519 secret keys. The corresponding public keys are part

of each InterestGroup used for negative targeting, and the browser will

first verify that one of the signatures of the additional bid matches

the key on the InterestGroup before allowing its use for negative

targeting. More details on this are available at

https://github.com/WICG/turtledove/issues/319#issuecomment-1666234926.



Bug: 1464874

Change-Id: I89a33a28dc973ca0f5cda7ecd92cbeebef214253

entry.title: Show prefetch redirects in the DevTools Network panel.
entry.content:
There are a few key parts here:



Keep a persistent network::ResourceRequest in PrefetchContainer.



When following a redirect that doesn't go to a new loader,

we're currently expected to supply a ResourceRequest, but

at present we only construct these when kicking off a new

loader. Instead, we construct it once and update it as it

needs to be changed, which is similar to how other sites

handle this.



Since the inputs required to construct this principally

exist in PrefetchContainer already, the logic to construct

it is moved there, except for the Accept header, which

depends on the BrowserContext. Fortunately that header does

not presently need to be changed on redirect.



Plumb redirect info to PrefetchRequestWillBeSent instrumentation.



An optional pair of the response URL (since this isn't otherwise

available once the location has changed due to redirect) and the

information extracted from the response head is plumbed in. This

is absent in the case of a non-redirect. This mirrors how this

is exposed in the DevTools protocol.



Inspector protocol tests for this behavior.



Because the ExtraInfo events come from the network service and

aren't guaranteed to be consistently sequenced with respect to

the other events dispatched from the browser process, the test

utility includes logic to reorder these events into a consistent

and meaningful order (similar to how the frontend deals with

these events for other fetches, which I've checked).



Bug: 1458582

Change-Id: I83a9077c45cff9e4bf92aa5916f51fdc22e8ebee

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4775927

entry.title: Remove `AgentSchedulingGroupHost::GetProcess()` DCHECK
entry.content:
https://crrev.com/c/2492281 introduced a commented out DCHECK() in

`AgentSchedulingGroupHost::GetProcess()` ensuring that method is never

called when its LifecycleState is in the `kRenderProcessHostDestroyed`

state.



It's commented out with the disclaimer above it, saying it cannot be enabled yet:



"since RenderViewHostImpl outlives its associated

AgentSchedulingGroupHost, and the [RenderViewHostImpl] dtor queries the

associated RenderProcessHost to remove itself from the

PerProcessRenderViewHostSet and RemoveObserver() itself."



However, this isn't exactly correct. The RVHI doesn't appear to actually

outlive its RPHI/ASGH; that would cause a different kind of crash/error

altogether. The flow I believe the comment intends to describe can be seen in various browser test failures that occur when the DCHECK is enabled, that look like:



```

#6 0x7f9375403d6d logging::CheckError::~CheckError()

#7 0x7f93609062e9 content::AgentSchedulingGroupHost::GetProcess()

#8 0x7f9360e507dd content::RenderViewHostImpl::GetProcess()

#9 0x7f9360e4dec6 content::RenderViewHostImpl::~RenderViewHostImpl()

#10 0x7f9360e4e339 content::RenderViewHostImpl::~RenderViewHostImpl()

```



What happens is `RenderViewHostImpl::dtor()` is called, which calls:

1. `GetAgentSchedulingGroup().RemoveRoute()` [1]

a. ASGH accomplishes this by going through its RenderProcessHostImpl

b. If this is the last route in the process, then

`RenderProcessHostImpl::Cleanup()` is invoked, which first alerts

all observers of the `RenderProcessHostDestroyed()` event, and

then immediately schedules its destruction in an asynchronous

task

2. `GetProcess().GetID()` and `GetProcess()->RemoveObserver()`

a. This fails because by this point, `AgentSchedulingGroup`, which

is-a `RenderProcessHostObserver`, has already been notified of

the `RenderProcessHostDestroyed` event, despite the RPHI still

being alive, although its destruction has been scheduled.



There are a few options to deal with this:

1. Move all invocations of methods that can trigger the

`RenderProcessHostDestroyed()` event — like `RemoveRoute()` — to

*after* any co-located calls to `GetProcess()`. This is really a

hack, and is very fragile. Even if implemented, it's probably not

actually possible to get this correct, since there are many calls

to `GetProcess()` from other classes, that happen far away from

calls to things like `RemoveRoute()`. That's what we see in [2],

where I tried to implement this.

And even still, if this were completely possible, it's very

undesirable because then you have to keep in mind the allowed

ordering of some random method invocations that might

arbitrarily change over time across classes. BAD!

2. Another solution is to weaken the DCHECK(), as to ensure that we

never call `GetProcess()` when `state_` is destroyed *unless* the

RPHI also has its `deleting_soon_` bool set to true, indicating

that destruction has been scheduled. We let this case slide because

there's nothing wrong with getting the RPHI at this point. In unit

tests, `MockRenderProcessHost` doesn't have an `deleting_soon_`

bool, so we'd have to have a special carve-out for this case, where

we just treat it as OK and pass the DCHECK() since we know we're

in a unit test.

This solution isn't bad, but unfortunately it's not possible to

implement since there is no way to detect whether `ASGH::process_`

is a `RenderProcessHostImpl` or a `MockRenderProcessHost`, so we

can't distinguish between the "production" and the "test" scenario.

3. A better solution would probably be to just remove the DCHECK()

since it's not doing anything useful. It's commented out, and even

if it were enabled, it wouldn't necessarily be correct. There's

nothing inherently wrong with consulting an RPHI in the gap between

`Cleanup()` and `::dtor()`, which is what the DCHECK prevents. The

DCHECK isn't protecting against accessing an already-actually-

destroyed RPHI anyways; that's what the `base::SafeRef` around

`AgentSchedulingGroupHost::process_` does!

Given the fact that this DCHECK() was probably misunderstood in the

first place — mistaking the RPHDestroyed() event for *actual*

destruction — and was put into place before the base::SafeRef

protection was implemented, which actually does something here,

I firmly believe this is the best solution forward. This CL removes

the DCHECK().





[1]: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/renderer_host/render_view_host_impl.cc;l=383-388;drc=31154961f51fd2c1116e37fbc7e2f0ea6099414e

[2]: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4226953/4?checksPatchset=4&tab=checks



Bug: 1111231

Change-Id: Icf40f0f0bc0d40642a5fb2b64a664fc204d7d906

entry.title: Fix PrintBrowserTest RunLoop initialization timing
entry.content:
The flakes tied to this bug happened by having the RunLoop

that populates `quit_callback_` in

`PrintBrowserTest::WaitUntilCallbackReceived`. With this

initialization timing, it became possible for

`PrintBrowserTest::CheckForQuit` to be called its expected number of

times before `WaitUntilCallbackReceived` was called. This lead to `quit_callback` being assigned after it would have been called on the last `CheckForQuit`.



This is fixed by moving the base::RunLoop into

a class member, and initializing `quit_callback_` in

`PrintBrowserTest::SetUpOnMainThread`.



Bug: b/298203775

Change-Id: I0b28e0625b0ca89c6a0dcecd350a1fe775ff7ad4

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4824365

Reviewed-by: Alan Screen

Commit-Queue: Dominique Fauteux-Chapleau

Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1190310}

entry.title: [QuickStart] Allow QuickStartMessage to decode unspecified payloads
entry.content:
This is the first in a chain of CLs that will allow QuickStartDecoder

to parse any packet from the source device and figure out its type.

Currently we have separate methods for decoding each packet type, which

makes it more difficult to handle packets that could be one of several

types.



This CL adds an overload of QuickStartMessage::ReadMessage() that does

not require an enum value specifying the packet type. Instead, it

determines the packet type by examining the packet. The original

ReadMessage() that does take a packet type now calls the new method

and simply checks that the decoded packet matches the expected type.



Bug: b/294253611

Test: Existing tests provide coverage, add test for unexpected msg.

Change-Id: Id6efd792057cbb78f5e103f933ef857f3590882e

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4794841

entry.title: Make sure PWAs have the correct colors in their BrowserThemePack.
entry.content:
Previously toolbar colors were incorrectly set in PWA windows, since by

default these are derived from active tab colors. In the case of PWAs

toolbar and active tab can be entirely different colors though.



So rather than reuse BrowserThemePack::BuildFromColors for PWA windows,

this CL adds a BrowserThemePack::BuildFromWebAppColors method that

populates the theme pack appropriately for web applications.



With ChromeRefresh2023 enabled on the other hand the toolbar color as

specified in BrowserThemePack is entirely ignored it seems, so also

override toolbar related colors in AppBrowserController's color mixer.



Also with ChromeRefresh2023 enabled, the page info icon no longer

calls its delegate to figure out what color ID to use for its foreground

and inkdrop colors, so make sure to populate these colors correctly in

the color mixer as well.



Also removes a now no longer needed work-around from ExtensionToolbarButton, which as a side effect fixes a bug where this

icon has the wrong color in inactive windows.

Other places with similar special case logic for PWAs will be updated

in follow-up CLs.



Finally, this changes WebAppBrowsertests that tried to verify that

changing a pages background color also changed the download shelf

color to instead verify the active tab color. The download shelf no

longer exists (and shouldn't have been using "toolbar" colors directly

even when it did). Fortunately the download shelf was the only UI

surface (that I've come across) that was hardcoded to using toolbar

colors rather than more specific color IDs.



Bug: 1414432

Change-Id: I744bf8d446215b64f8830d590390162c32fca542

Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4236152

Reviewed-by: Peter Kasting

Commit-Queue: Marijn Kruisselbrink

entry.title: Skip PolicyCacheProvider when empty.
entry.content:
The cached policy provider flushes policies to native before the

normal providers register. This causes the PolicyService to

initialize before the real app restrictions are available. This

results in very undesirable behavior in the FRE when we act on the

wrong policy values.



To mitigate this, no-op the PolicyCacheProvider, and just never call

notifySettingsAvailable or onSettingsAvailable, so that policies are

not flushed to native yet. This will cause the Java FRE code to wait

longer until app restrictions are correctly applied.



Bug: b/290072097

Change-Id: I8ea540345d90b6b496f043f4849d9238686d1126

entry.title: Create cr-chip
entry.content:
After talking to UX, it seems that the chip element should be basically

the same as what was built in sp-filter-chip, except it should have

paper ripple. Therefore, the CSS is largely borrowed from

sp-filter-chip.



This does not currently support suggestion chips, but that could easily

be added as a class for it, just like we do with button types.



Some things to note:

* I used an attribute "chip-role" for passing the role through since

role seems to be used by polymer and I wasn't sure how screenreaders

would take a nested role attribute since it would show in the DOM.

* Unlike sp-filter-chip, this chip component is not keeping track of

filtered and disabled within the ts since it doesn't need to pass it

on to the inner button.

* This chip component expects the parent to handle basically all of the

action logic and is mostly styling.

* The padding and hover color were updated vs sp-filter-chip to match

designs.



Screenshots:

GM3: http://screenshot/4RY8TnZTaMMFHza

GM2: http://screenshot/3AXuPDpkk7UAPER



NOTE for GM2: I don't have designs for this so it is just matching

sp-filter-chip.

entry.title: Introduce CustomTabs.Startup.TimeToLargestContentfulPaint
entry.content:
Followup to https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4811394



Adds a new metric for Custom Tabs startup until the Largest Contentful

Paint for the first navigation, split by various levels of

warmed-up-ness.



For cold starts, using the process creation time rather than the

intent received time will better represent the difference between warm

and cold starts. For warm cases the intent received/oncreate time are

the earliest measurable points for when startup began.

entry.title: Reland "webview(metrics): Fix host package information in SDK runtime"
entry.content:
This reverts commit a7d7194ef04c37c3cc1da39070acf2502a2bd4ee.



Reason for revert: The issue was we were making use of the new SDK qualified package name that isn't actually a package name.

There are two requests for the installer info that relied on this "qualified" package name resulting in a failure.

It doesn't seem to fail consistently.

Fixed by retrieving installer information for the actual installed app and making the metrics rely on this too.



I tested this by rerunning the SDK Runtime CTS tests we caused to fail

and confirming that they all pass.



Original change's description:

> Revert "webview(metrics): Fix host package information in SDK runtime"

>

> This reverts commit b98c18ec53e4840458a8e8d06b38550bff73da35.

>

> Reason for revert: breaks Webview Sandbox CTS. The blamelist on the first failing CI run was bisected and this came back as the culprit.

>

> Please confirm locally that the Webview Sandbox CTS passes before relanding.

>

> Original change's description:

> > webview(metrics): Fix host package information in SDK runtime

> >

> > The context we retrieve for the SDK runtime is a generic

> > sdksandbox context. This results in our metrics and minidumps

> > reporting a generic package name that won't help

> > for investigating issues.

> >

> > The good news is that the uid for the SDK sandbox

> > process does belong to the host app and there is a deterministic

> > relationship between the SDK process and the host app

> > so we can get the host apps information from it.

> >

> > The one tricky bit is that this trick doesn't apply to the

> > render process because it is an isolated process and so

> > doesn't have this same relationship.

> > We settled on feeding this through as a command line

> > switch.

> >

> > I unfortunately haven't added tests because we don't

> > have any instrumentation tests for the SDK runtime

> > and this behavior is wildly environment specific.

> > I just tested it manually with a shell app that contains

> > a WebView and also confirmed that the mini dumps show

> > correctly in the dev UI when I induce a crash with

> > chrome://crash. I have also tested this against staging

> > crashpad and confirmed that the crashes show up there.

> >

> > Low-Coverage-Reason: We don't have Rb infrastructure for tests

> > Bug: 1464923

> > Change-Id: Ifa063299caeed57679d99febe90b2e95cbb09ee8

> > Reviewed-on: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4720129

> > Commit-Queue: Rupert Wiser

> > Reviewed-by: Alexander Timin

> > Reviewed-by: Richard Coles

> > Reviewed-by: Luc Nguyen

> > Cr-Commit-Position: refs/heads/main@{#1186353}

>

entry.title: [PDF OCR] Compute and set the OCR batch size based on the page count
entry.content:
Compute and set the OCR batch size according to the following formula:

batch size = page count * 0.1; (min = 1, max = 20)



This dynamic batch size helps PDF OCR to minimize the latency of

providing OCR results for users and control the number of tree updates

in a PDF accessibility tree depending on the page count.



AX-Relnotes: n/a.

entry.title: [omnibox][webui] Rewrite presenter sizing logic without GetTargetBounds
entry.content:
This CL replaces the GetTargetBounds method from the presenter with a

simpler and more direct sizing implementation that always sets the

correct fixed width based on the location bar view's bounds. The old

GetTargetBounds code was originally developed for the views popup and

wasn't working correctly for the webui popup. Sizing now appears to be

correct after every update, but note that some TODOs still remain.

Responding to changes in the browser window size should be easier after

this change because we always specify the exact width for the web

contents, instead of having separate init and update logic as before.

entry.title: [Mac System Hotkeys] Skip undocumented AppleSymbolicHotKeys
entry.content:
When you change the shortcuts for Spaces Left and Spaces Right, macOS

inserts your new shortcuts at slots 79 and 81 in AppleSymbolicHotKeys.

For some reason, it also inserts "shifted" versions of these

shortcuts at slots 80 and 82. It's unclear why these shifted versions

exist because the shortcuts don't seem to do anything. They could be

entries macOS adds for some reason but knows to skip (not expecting

any non-system application to read this file). Treating these

shortcuts as valid, which is what Chrome has been doing, creates

unexpected behavior. For example, in the case of "Spaces Left" being

mapped to Option Left Arrow, this extra shortcut causes Chrome to

silently ignore Shift-Option Left Arrow, the shortcut which appends

the current text selection by one word to the left. This cl works

around the problem by changing the SystemHotkeyMap to ignore these

two undocumented shortcuts.



This is a reland of https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3908188 . This version forgoes the file watcher setup that broke web apps (aiming for a separate reland of that code).

--gtest_filter=SystemHotkeyMapTest.IgnoreUndocumentedShortcutEntries

entry.title: [anchor-position] Support margin properties in position fallback
entry.content:
This patch makes margin properties (except margin-trim) allowed in a

@position-fallback rule, so that different fallback positions can use

different margins.



There's also some changes to `getComputedStyle()` implementation to

make it return the used margin values from fallback styles. To do so,

we unconditionally obtain the result from a `LayoutBox` if the current

object is a box. Since the result is available only after layout, this

patch also changes all margin properties on boxes to be layout

dependent, regardless of the computed margin values.



Note: This causes some rounding differences, as the result from

`LayoutBox`, which is the actual layout precision, has a fixed-point

precision of 1/64 px. Therefore, some tests are rebaselined.

entry.content:
Adds CompanionAppBroker family of classes to manage companion app

logic. Modifies FastPairPresenterImpl and quick pair Mediator to

surface the fast pair companion app notification based on minimal

logic. Updates Mediator and derived class definitions to include

references to the new CompanionAppBroker class.



Adds unit tests for FastPairPresenterImpl to account for the newly

surfaced notification.

functions as expected. Quick pair unit tests pass.
